'''Speak & Read''' is an [[Electronics|electronic]] [[Instructional technology|learning aid]] made in 1980, by [[Texas Instruments]]. Speak and Read was part of a family of learning [[toy]]s i.e. "[[Speak & Math]]" and "[[Speak & Spell (toy)|Speak & Spell]]".
Speak & Read helped children from ages four to eight develop and improve their reading comprehension and vocabulary. <ref>http://smithsonianchips.si.edu/texas/ref433.htm</ref> Speak & Read came with a companion booklet for use with the skill activity modes included in the unit. The toy had a vocabulary of 250 words.<ref>http://www.datamath.org/Speech/SpeaknRead.htm</ref>
== Electronics == The display was a [[vacuum fluorescent display]] (VFD). Speak & Read units used a membrane keyboard for input. The Speak & Read used a single-chip voice synthesizer, the TI [[TMC0280]] (later called the TMS5100), that was also used in the Speak & Spell. The TMS5100 used a 10th-order [[linear predictive coding]] (LPC) model and the electronic [[Digital signal processing|DSP]] logic.<ref>History Channel, '''Modern Marvels: ''"70s Tech"''', 2007, aired 6:00-7:00pm MST</ref>
LPC encoded speech data was stored on a pair of [[TMS6100]] 128 Kbit (a very large capacity ROM in the early 1980s) metal gate serial PMOS ROMs. Additional memory modules could be plugged into a slot in the battery compartment and selected via a button on the keyboard. A later model, the Super Speak & Read, had a much slimmer case and an [[Liquid crystal display|LCD]] screen rather than a VFD screen.
The unit could use either 4 "C" batteries or 6 volt [[Direct current|DC]] power adapter with positive tip polarity.
The game has been emulated in 2015 by [[MESS]].
== Games included == Speak & Read had six built-in learning games: Word Zap, Word Maker, Read It, Picture Read, Letter Stumper, and Hear It. Picture Read required looking up pictures in the supplementary booklet that came with the unit. Eight expansion modules were known to have been made for the Speak & Read by 1986.<ref>http://www.datamath.org/Speech/Images/SpeaknRead.jpg</ref>
